properties.description: Execute a complete ATM transaction workflow using a state machine that handles customer interaction, bank communication, and transaction completion.
properties.howItWorks: This method implements a state machine to orchestrate the complete ATM transaction process. It transitions through states including getting transaction specifics from customer, sending to bank, handling invalid PIN scenarios, completing the transaction, printing receipts, and asking if user wants to do another transaction. The method coordinates multiple components including CustomerConsole for user interaction, NetworkToBank for bank communication, and ReceiptPrinter for transaction documentation. It handles various exception scenarios including customer cancellation and card retention, ensuring robust transaction processing with proper state management and user feedback.
properties.howToUse: Call this method to initiate and execute a complete ATM transaction workflow. The method is typically invoked by the ATM session handler and will manage the entire transaction lifecycle automatically. The method blocks until the transaction is complete and returns a boolean indicating whether the customer wants to perform another transaction. Ensure the transaction object is properly initialized with ATM reference, customer information, and transaction type before calling this method.
postConditions: Transaction workflow is completed with either success or cancellation
Receipt is printed if transaction was successful
Customer console displays appropriate messages throughout the process
Network communication with bank is completed
State machine reaches final ASKING_DO_ANOTHER_STATE
Method returns boolean indicating customer's desire to perform another transaction
preConditions: Transaction object is properly initialized with ATM instance reference
Customer session is valid and authenticated
Transaction type is set (withdrawal, deposit, transfer, etc.)
Required transaction data structures are allocated (balances, message objects)
ATM components (CustomerConsole, NetworkToBank, ReceiptPrinter) are available and functional
properties.returns: Boolean value indicating whether the customer wants to perform another transaction (true) or end the session (false)

properties.docComment: Ejecting the customer's card

properties.description: Initialize a new Deposit transaction by delegating to the parent Transaction constructor with the provided ATM, session, card, and PIN parameters.
properties.howItWorks: This constructor receives four parameters: an ATM object, a Session object, a Card object, and a PIN integer. It immediately delegates initialization to the parent Transaction class constructor using the super() method call. The parent constructor handles the actual initialization logic including assigning a unique serial number and setting initial state for the transaction.
properties.howToUse: Call this constructor with valid ATM, Session, Card, and PIN objects to create a new Deposit transaction instance. Ensure all parameters are properly initialized and the PIN matches the card's PIN for successful transaction creation. This constructor is typically used by the ATM system when a customer initiates a deposit operation.
postConditions: A new Deposit transaction object is created and initialized
The transaction has a unique serial number assigned by the parent constructor
The transaction is in initial state ready for processing
All provided parameters are stored and accessible for later transaction operations
preConditions: The atm parameter must be a valid, non-null ATM object
The session parameter must be a valid, non-null Session object
The card parameter must be a valid, non-null Card object
The pin parameter must be a valid integer representing the customer's PIN
properties.returns: A newly initialized Deposit transaction object that extends the Transaction class functionality for deposit-specific operations.

Representation for customer's current account balances as returned by the

Provides accessor methods to retrieve balance values and a mutator method to update both balances simultaneously. Serves as a simple data container for banking transaction processing.

properties.docComment: The ATM's cash dispenser

properties.description: (no description)

properties.docComment:
Abstract base class for representation of various status codes returned
 by bank for a transaction.  The bank will create appropriate subclasses.
properties.description: Abstract base class that defines a contract for representing different status outcomes in banking operations. Provides standardized methods to check operation success, validate PIN status, and retrieve descriptive messages. Serves as a foundation for concrete status implementations like success and failure states in the ATM simulation system.

The atm.transaction package provides a comprehensive framework for ATM transaction processing in the gravity-atmsimulator system. It contains an abstract Transaction base class that defines the common workflow and state management for all ATM operations, along with four concrete implementations for specific transaction types: Inquiry (balance checks), Transfer (account-to-account transfers), Deposit (fund deposits), and Withdrawal (cash dispensing). The package also includes a custom exception for handling card retention scenarios. This design follows a template method pattern where the abstract base class coordinates the overall transaction workflow while delegating transaction-specific operations to subclasses. The package encapsulates the core banking logic and business rules for ATM operations, managing customer interactions, bank communications, PIN validation, and transaction completion processes.
properties.title: ATM Transaction Processing Framework

properties.docComment: Inform the ATM that a card has been inserted into the card reader.
properties.description: Marks that a bank card has been inserted into the ATM and notifies waiting threads of this state change.
properties.howItWorks: This synchronized method sets the internal cardInserted flag to true, indicating that a card has been inserted. The synchronized keyword ensures thread-safe access to the state variable. The notify() call awakens any threads that might be waiting for this event to occur, enabling coordination between different components of the ATM simulation.
properties.howToUse: This method is typically called when a physical card insertion event is detected by the simulation. It should be invoked after verifying the card's validity and before proceeding with transaction processing. The method assumes that the calling context has appropriate synchronization or coordination requirements.
postConditions: The cardInserted flag is set to true
Any waiting threads are notified of the state change
The method maintains thread-safety through synchronization
preConditions: The ATM object must be properly initialized
The calling context must have appropriate synchronization considerations
The method should only be called once per card insertion event
properties.returns: void

It knows facts about different account types (abbreviations and names) and provides this information to other components without implementing complex business logic or services.

This class belongs to the Logic architectural layer because it contains domain-specific business information about account types within the banking system. It provides data structures that support the application logic while being independent of UI presentation, data persistence, or external service interactions.

The Receipt class serves as a data container that stores and provides structured access to transaction information through organized string arrays and enumeration methods. It maintains transaction state and formatting without performing complex business logic.

This class operates in the Logic layer as it handles application-level data formatting and organization for transaction receipts. It structures domain data (transaction details, balances, metadata) for downstream display/printing but doesn't handle UI rendering, data persistence, or user interactions directly.
The primary responsibility is handling user interface and GUI display, serving as the graphical container for the ATM simulation that users directly interact with through the applet framework.

This class clearly operates in the UI layer as it handles the graphical user interface, applet display setup, GUI panel management, and visual components. It focuses on user interaction and presentation rather than application logic or data access.
This class specifically handles user interface display functionality for the ATM simulation, managing text output, formatting, and visual presentation to the user through AWT Label components.

The class is part of the user interface layer as it directly manages AWT components (Labels, Panel, LayoutManager), handles visual presentation with colors and fonts, and provides display functionality for user-facing output in the ATM simulation.

This class directly handles user input/output through UI components (Button and TextArea) and manages the user interaction flow for collecting printed receipts, making it primarily responsible for user interface functionality.

The class uses java.awt components (Button, TextArea) and focuses entirely on user interface functionality, visual layout management, and user interaction handling rather than business logic or data access operations.

This class handles user input/output through the keyboard interface, managing user interactions in an ATM simulation and providing real-time feedback through display updates, making it a classic User Interfacer that bridges user actions with the underlying ATM system logic.

The class creates and manages UI components (buttons, keyboard layout), handles user interactions and keyboard events, and focuses on visual and interactive elements of the ATM simulation, placing it firmly in the UI layer of the application architecture.

This class serves as a simple data container that holds monetary information (in cents) and provides basic operations on that data. It doesn't make complex decisions or coordinate between components, but rather encapsulates and manages monetary values as a fundamental domain object.

The Money class implements core domain logic for handling monetary calculations and operations. It provides essential functionality for the banking domain (arithmetic operations, comparisons, string formatting) that is neither UI-related nor data access related, making it a fundamental component of the application's business logic layer.

The class primarily handles user input/output operations and coordinates the user interface flow for the ATM simulator. It manages user interactions through various panels, displays different views based on user actions, and provides methods for capturing user input (like card reading and cash initialization). The class acts as the main interface between users and the underlying ATM simulation components.

The class is clearly in the UI layer as it handles user interface operations including instantiating GUI components (panels, layouts), setting up the visual layout using GridBagLayout, managing widget positioning through CardLayout, capturing user interactions (card input, cash amount entry), and displaying information to users through various panels. The class doesn't contain business logic or data access operations but focuses purely on presentation and user interaction coordination.

The ATM class acts as a central coordinator that delegates work across different components and subsystems. It doesn't implement specific business logic but orchestrates the flow between the card reader, cash dispenser, network connection, and session management, coordinating state transitions and managing the overall ATM workflow.

The ATM class operates in the Logic layer as it contains the core application logic and business coordination for the ATM system. It handles state management, workflow coordination, and system orchestration rather than UI presentation or data persistence. The class manages the main application flow and coordinates between different subsystems without being responsible for user interface or data access operations.

This class primarily serves as an information container that holds and provides specific cancellation information. It encapsulates the reason for cancellation ("Cancelled by customer") and provides a standardized way to represent this state throughout the ATM system.

This class belongs to the logic layer because it handles domain-specific exception handling and business logic for the ATM system. It represents a business concept (customer cancellation) and is not related to UI, data access, or physical hardware interfaces.

The CardReader class primarily coordinates activities between the ATM system and the simulation engine by delegating card reading, ejection, and retention operations to the central Simulation singleton, without implementing the core logic itself.

The CardReader class operates in the Logic layer as it coordinates and manages card processing operations without directly handling user interface elements or data storage, focusing on the business logic of card management within the ATM system.

This class implements a state machine that makes decisions and directs the flow of ATM transactions, coordinating between multiple components including customer interface, bank network, and session management to orchestrate the complete transaction process.

The class handles application and domain logic for ATM transaction processing, managing transaction state, workflow coordination, and business rules. It doesn't handle UI widget creation, data access, or external service I/O, but rather implements the core transactional logic that governs how ATM operations are performed.

This class acts as a data container that holds state information about banking operations, providing access to status data through standardized accessor methods. It encapsulates status-related data (success/failure state, PIN validity, descriptive messages) without performing complex business logic, making it primarily an information repository.

This class handles application and domain logic for banking operations, specifically managing status representation and validation logic for ATM transactions. It operates in the business logic layer by defining the contract for status handling without dealing with UI presentation or data access operations.

The Transfer class performs specific services for transfer transactions through well-defined methods including customer interaction, message creation, and receipt generation, following the service provider pattern.

The Transfer class handles application domain logic for ATM transfer transactions, coordinating between user input collection, banking system communication, and transaction processing without handling UI, data access, or external I/O operations directly.

The Withdrawal class implements the specific service of handling ATM cash withdrawal transactions through a focused set of methods that perform withdrawal-specific operations like customer input collection, cash dispensing coordination, and receipt generation.

The Withdrawal class operates in the Logic layer as it implements core domain business logic for ATM withdrawal operations, handling transaction workflow coordination and business rules without being concerned with UI presentation, data persistence, or external service integration.

The Deposit class handles specific deposit service requests by providing focused functionality for processing deposit transactions. It implements the abstract transaction methods to offer deposit-specific services including customer interaction, envelope collection, and bank communication.

The Deposit class operates in the Logic layer as it handles application and domain logic for deposit transactions. It contains business rules for deposit processing, customer validation, and transaction workflow coordination without directly managing UI presentation or data persistence.

The Inquiry class implements a specific transaction type (inquiry) that handles customer requests and performs the service of retrieving account balance information, fitting the Service Provider stereotype as it provides specialized functionality for a particular use case.

The Inquiry class handles application-specific domain logic for ATM inquiry transactions, managing the workflow and business rules for balance inquiries without handling UI rendering or data persistence, making it part of the Logic layer.

This class is a simple data structure that holds information about successful banking operations. It provides straightforward getter methods (isSuccess, getMessage, isInvalidPIN) to access status information without containing complex business logic or service implementations. It acts as a plain object for representing successful transaction outcomes.

This class represents domain logic for banking operations by providing a concrete implementation of the Status abstraction specifically for successful outcomes. It contains no UI components, data access logic, or external service interactions, focusing solely on representing the success state and related information within the banking domain model.

This class primarily serves as a data container for storing and providing access to failure status information. It maintains a message field and provides getter methods to access this information, following the Information Holder stereotype by holding and exposing data about failure conditions without performing complex business logic.

This class belongs to the Logic architectural layer as it represents core domain concepts in the banking simulation. It models business-level status outcomes and failure conditions rather than handling user interface concerns, data access operations, or external system interactions. The class is part of the domain model that defines the behavior and state of banking transaction results.
This class functions as a data holder that encapsulates information about an invalid PIN condition, providing both the error message and boolean status indicator through its isInvalidPIN() method.

This class handles application and domain logic related to authentication failures in the banking simulation, representing business rule violations rather than UI interactions or data access operations.

The simulation package is primarily classified as the UI layer because the vast majority of its classes are dedicated to user interface creation and management. The package contains 14 UI-focused classes that extend AWT/Swing components (Panel, TextField, Button, etc.) and handle user interactions through ActionListeners. The central Simulation class primarily coordinates UI components, while GUI and ATMPanel classes manage overall interface layout and panel orchestration. Even the SimulatedBank class, while containing business logic, serves as a UI-driven simulation component rather than a pure data access layer. The package's primary responsibility is creating and managing the visual and interactive aspects of the ATM simulator.

The banking package contains core domain model classes and abstractions that represent the fundamental concepts of a banking system, including monetary values, account balances, transaction messages, and status/ receipt abstractions. These classes encapsulate the core domain logic and data structures without implementing UI rendering, data persistence, or the detailed business rules themselves. They serve as a foundation for the business logic layer, providing the essential domain entities and abstractions that define the banking system's conceptual model.

The atm.transaction package handles core application and domain logic for ATM transaction processing. It contains the business rules, workflow management, and transaction coordination logic that defines how different types of ATM operations are executed. This is neither user interface code nor data access code, but rather the central logic layer that processes ATM transactions according to banking business rules and coordinates between the customer interface and bank systems.

The atm.physical package fits the Logic architectural layer as it handles domain-specific business logic for ATM operations, specifically managing physical device interactions and coordinating ATM functionality. While it interfaces with physical devices, its primary responsibility is implementing the core ATM transaction logic, user interaction flows, and system coordination rather than UI presentation, data persistence, or low-level hardware I/O. Each class encapsulates business rules around their respective devices (cash dispensing logic, card reading procedures, network communication protocols) and provides a service interface for the ATM application logic.

The atm package contains core business logic and coordination logic rather than UI, data access, or physical hardware implementation. It orchestrates the ATM workflow, manages state transitions, coordinates between subsystems, and implements the central business rules for ATM operations. While it interfaces with physical devices and transactions, its primary responsibility is applying business logic and coordinating system behavior, making it fit the Logic architectural layer.
